Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CSR: Enabling Efficient Non-Volatile Processors on Energy Harvesting Powered Embedded Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on enabling correct and efficient software execution on non-volatile processors (NVP) for energy harvesting powered embedded systems. NVPs work with unstable harvested energy sources vital for applications such as wearable devices and the Internet of Things (IoT). Software specifically optimized for NVPs is important in that it allows an NVP to function correctly and is key for realizing embedded systems that are energy efficient, user-friendly, and environmentally-friendly. Compared with current devices that need regular maintenance, this project will enable a new class of maintenance free NVP-based embedded devices.

Addressing a critical technology gap as it enables NVP-based embedded systems, the techniques developed in this project will provide tools to automatically transform existing NVP software. In addition to the education and training opportunities this research will allow, the success of this project will enable an energy-efficient, reliable, and resilient NVP solution that provides cumulative execution for energy harvesting embedded systems making small energy harvesting based embedded devices more practical across a wide range of applications, including healthcare, and military innovation and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to develop compiler optimization techniques to enable efficient and correct program execution on non-volatile processors (NVP) so that NVP-based embedded systems can run with intermittent energy harvested from ambient environment. The ultimate goal is to realize embedded systems such as sensors to run with little to none maintenance effort.  

Through this project, the PI and his students designed both hardware and software techniques to realize efficient and reliable computation with intermittent power harvested from the ambient environment. The PI and his students developed novel stack trimming, dynamic checkpointing selection techniques to improve the efficiency of checkpointing such that the majority of the energy can be utilized for computing. We also developed a compiler optimization to eliminate inconsistency errors introduced by frequent power failures. Novel hybrid cache architecture and online task scheduling, wake-up voltage selection, and dynamic voltage scaling techniques are also developed to improve energy utlization. 

This project supports 2 PhD students, one of whom is female and will join University of Texas at San Antonio as an Assistant Professor. This project also supports several undergraduate students with REU supplement. The research outcome is integrated into computer engineering curriculum at both Oklahoma State University and University of Pittsburgh. This project provides demonstration to local high school students in Oklahoma through National Lab Day. This project also enriches PITT summer school for local K-12 students. This summer school offers interesting opportunities for under-represented students, such as female, African American, and Hispanic students.

The research works are used as competition problems for ACM CADathlon Competition. It is a challenging programming competition sponsored by ACM/SIGDA, which focuses on practical problems at the forefront of Electronic Design Automation. Known as the “Olympic games of EDA,” the contest brings together the best and the brightest of the next generation of CAD professionals. It helps attract top graduate students to the EDA field.
